newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines' Ramos undergoes surgery, recuperating.
newsitem.headline: Philippines' Ramos undergoes surgery, recuperating.

text.p: Philippines President Fidel Ramos successfully underwent surgery on Monday, a day after suddenly being taken ill, and was recovering well, officials said.
"President Ramos is awake, he's smiling, he's listening to radio," Jose de Venecia, speaker of the House of Representatives, told reporters. "The operation was extremely successful."
Senate President Ernesto Maceda said in a statement that Ramos was to have undergone cardiovascular surgery but other officials refused to give details of the operation.

Executive Secretary Ruben Torres told reporters after a cabinet meeting at the presidential palace that the surgery, which began at 7 a.m. (2300 GMT Sunday), lasted about 90 minutes and that Ramos was recuperating.
Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero said the surgery was successful and the president was in "super" condition.

Ramos, 68, was admitted to hospital for the second time in 10 days on Sunday, and doctors initially said he was to undergo follow-up checks following his confinement to bed the previous weekend for a throat infection.
But television reports late on Sunday said doctors suspected a blockage in an artery and were preparing for an angiography test.

News of Ramos being admitted to hospital hit the local stock market hard on Monday. The Philippine Composite Index was down 1.92 percent at 3,119.28 points at mid-morning. while the peso was slightly weaker at 26.310/316 against the dollar from 26.301 on Friday.
Ramos had set off alarm bells on Manila's bourse and corporate boardrooms when he was admitted to the hospital on December 12 and some newspapers reported he had suffered a mild stroke.
He was released three days later after being treated for what doctors said was a throat infection.
Ramos resumed a heavy schedule of speaking engagements and other public appearances shortly after he checked out, apparently to scotch the rumours of serious ill-health.
Doctors urged him to slow down and Ramos cancelled a series of provincial trips.
He told his weekly news conference on Wednesday he was in good health and that jitters in the stock market over his health appeared to be over.

Ramos's hospital spells coincided with a controversy over calls by a citizens' group to amend the constitution to allow him to run for re-election when his six-year term ends in June 1998. The constitution limits a president to a single term.
